ratings.comment: Chanwoo was hard to understand, came late and unprepared to lecture, failed to properly answer questions, and constantly messed up and seemed like he didn't understand the concepts himself. He was a nice guy, just not a very informed professor.

He did not teach; I had previously taken calculus in high school and spent my entire semester teaching my friends the curriculum. If I didn't have previous experience I would have failed. Would get problems wrong every lecture while doing them on the board and then would just move on knowing that he was wrong. DO NOT TAKE.
Good luck, he doesn't teach and reads his slides instead of explaining what's going on.

Chanwoo is the absolute worst teacher I have ever encountered. If I didn't have previous calc experience, I wouldn't have done well. His lectures are a waste of time, and he's incapable of answering questions. I ended up using his class time to teach my friends what was going on. He's also mean and insufferable. DON'T TAKE.

If you have special circumstances with needing to miss something, or requesting extra time on things, he is not someone that is understanding and will not care. Your entire grade is determined based on midterms so if you do bad at the beginning, your grade will not be able to get improved much. His teaching is showing proofs that are irrelevant.
His lectures are horrible. He says so many things but nothing at the same time. You have to teach yourself if you want to do even ok.
He is probably the worst teacher I have ever had. I can teach my self better. He says so many words, but so little at the same time.

Chanwoo was a terrible teacher. Lectures consist of reading off the textbook and doing problems wrong half the time. Wasn't clear whatsoever and I found that lectures aren't a great use of time. Get ready to teach yourself calculus.

If you haven't taken AP Calc and don't wanna spend 50 hours a week as they recommend in the syllabus, save yourself the time and just get a tutor now because he teaches the material wrong half the time and just reads over slides super fast, refusing to explain or go back.
Very unclear with directions

He was very bad at explaining the subject and is hard to understand sometimes. The only reason I did well was because I had taken this class in high school. DO NOT recommend this class with this professor.

Not a good lecturer by any means. Hard to understand as well. Everyone I know who takes this class, including myself, realized early on that lecture isn't helpful in the slightest. Hopefully you have a good TA or get ready to teach yourself calculus.

He teaches horribly. Reads out of textbook most of the time, but half of the time will do problems wrong. When someone asked in lecture how to improve in class and on exams, his response was "just do better".

The professor knows the subject matter well, and is kind and goes around during problems and helps students. But sometimes his lectures were hard to follow for too many proofs. He always answered questions very effectively.

Took calc 234 online in the fall of 2021. Professor's recorded lectures involved him reading directly from the provided textbook powerpoint. Frequently the online exams would not be available at the designated time. The only reason I passed this class is because of Professor Lenard's phenomenal youtube videos.

Lectures didn't help me learn at all. He would just read from the textbook, so it was essentially like teaching yourself Calc 3. Homework and discussion worksheets prepare you pretty well for the weekly midterms. I took it in Fall 2020 and his video lectures would have voices of his children crying in the background which was pretty annoying.

Chanwoo was a decent lecturer at best. He didn't always seem to have a good grasp on the topic and it was pretty clear that he was just reading from the textbook most of the time, but the few examples he did give were decently useful. I wouldn't take another class with him, but he won't hinder your success in the course or anything.
i took math 222 with chanwoo in fall 2019. he uses proofs to explain concepts, his accent was hard to understand, and he made so many mistakes to the point that multiple people needed to correct him.
Professor is kind and lectures were decent although quite dry. His reviews and practice problems before the exams were quite helpful.

Prof Kim is very proof heavy. He does do practice problems but they are limited. His class isn't too exciting, although he does crack jokes sometimes which makes class entertaining. This is a hard class so be ready to work even for people who are good at math. Sometimes he skips a lot of steps so be sure your algebra skills are up to par.

Chanwoo's lectures are dry and are only proofs. We had a sub before our second midterm who went over all the topics and I got a 93 on the exam while the other exam I got a 75. He is a terrible professor who does not teach lectures well and is hard to understand. The only hope is discussion sections.

Chanwoo spends his time droning on and on about proofs and doesn't actually give information about what will be on the exams. When we had a substitute professor come in for review about the midterm, I understood more in their lectures in comparison to those of Chanwoo. I highly do not recommend him.
The lectures are very dry and boring. Chanwoo makes so many mistakes and doesnt realize it until someone calls him out. He is difficult to understand and doesnt explain in an easy to understand way

Ok first of all, I agree that his lecture is quite boring and useless proofs. However, he is not as bad as other reviews say. He cares about his student but doesn't realize nobody cares about proofs. His exams are easy as long as you do your homework. The only problem is it is very long and calculation extensive. You just have to be FAST!

This professor is clearly does not care about this class at all, and it shows in his lack of care with his lectures. At one point the entire class had to tell him that nobody understood anything past the first chalk board - he was six boards deep. Not at all approachable and not at all helpful.

Lectures are very boring, with little explanation of what is going on. He will start long proofs, taking about half of the power lecture, and not explain what he is actually doing until the end. Most often, it turns out to be useless, as you are not tested on proofs. Exams are based heavily on homework, so be sure to understand every problem.
Everyone else is saying exactly what I thought. Stopped going to lecture once I knew it wasn't helping. Taught myself from the textbook. Fortunate to end up with an A.

Kim's dry lectures come straight out of the textbook, but so do the exam problems. His ability to field questions and give feedback are non-existent (and one time he lied about an midterm's length and content). Still, his exams are remarkably simple (every question has already been done in homework or lecture). Easy A, but you won't learn anything.

Ridiculously boring lecturer with nothing but monotone. Doesn't explain things in any depth. Takes up half of class doing some extremely long useless abstract proofs that nobody understands. Purposely makes tests way more difficult than they need to be and doesn't allow note cards. Do yourself a huge  favor and get a different professor.

Professor Kim is a slow and tough grader who returned our first midterm after the class drop deadline. He barely gives partial credits. He constantly assigns homework, most weekly. He always makes computational mistakes during lectures using simple examples. However, in His second midterm and final, he gives us extremely complex computation.

If you have never taken calc before and taking 211, be prepared to teach it to yourself or with a tutor. He really did not seem to care very much about the class. A lot of people just stopped going to lecture because it was typically very unclear. He definitely knows how to do the math but he did a poor job of teaching the class how to do it.

Do not take 211 with this professor. He is obviously highly educated, but is not clear in communicating his ideas to the class and uses examples straight out of the text -- would have gotten the same grade not going to the class.
Awful professor. Could care less about his students. Lectures are completely unclear and most students stopped going. Be prepared to teach yourself from the textbook.
To be brief, Professor Kim's lectures were very confusing and unhelpful. Most of the reviews on here sum it up perfectly. I WOULD NOT RECOMMEND!

DO NOT TAKE HIM. His lectures are a joke, he assigns 4 problems for homework each week, he does nothing outside of the textbook. His first two midterms were okay, then his final ruined everyone, the class average was a 59%. He gave no practice problems for the final. Overall terrible professor, he should not be at a university like this.

I took AB calc in high school and had to take this again because I didn't get a 4. I went to the first four lectures and learned nothing of value. This was a 5 credit class and I only went to the one lecture on Monday to hand in my homework. None of the instruction of this course was helpful at all. Expect to learn on your own.
Horrible teacher. Get help as soon as possible if you are unfortunate enough to have him.

Chanwoo is one of the worst professors I've had at Madison. He acts like he is teaching the chalkboard and not the class. He goes through examples without explaining what he is doing. It is also hard to understand him sometimes. I would not recommend Chanwoo for math 211

This guy is AWFUL do not take him. He could care less about the class, speaks with his back to you and doesn't even explain what he is doing. He barely communicates with the TA's so they are about as helpful as a brick wall. Horrible class..
Terrible at teaching. Obviously a very smart guy who knows calculus, but he can hardly speak english, let alone teach. I'd stay away

Lectures are very confusing and not very helpful. Does not give much information that relates to the test. Make sure to get a tutor ASAP because there are only 4 assigned problems every week therefore you don't get much practice.
